item.description: Labs are complete for the semester. Great job, and good luck on the final!
Labs are complete for the semester. Great job, and good luck on the final!

item.title: Lab 10: Tick Data Collection + Vector-borne Disease Paper Discussion
item.description: This week we’ll be identifying the ticks we got from last week’s lab (and from iNaturalist), and then will be having a discussion on Shapiro et al., 2017 Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… First LO Second LO Presentation Lab 10 Presentation Worksheet Lab 10 Worksheet Resources To be added

item.title: Lab 11: Unique Host-Parasite Systems!
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… First LO Second LO Presentation Lab 11 Presentation Worksheet Lab 11 Worksheet Resources To be added

item.title: Lab 1: Lab Setup/Parasite Diversity/Microscope Basics
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Describe the overall structure of the laboratory course, expectations for laboratory conduct, and how their grade is assessed Successfully demonstrate how to use a compound light microscope, including loading specimen slides, focusing at multiple magnifications, calculating total magnification, and to accurately measure the size of objects under magnification Label the basic parts of a compound microscope and be able to explain their function Define parasitism (in an ecological sense), identify major parasitic groups of interest, and outline some of the life history strategies lumped together under the term “parasite” Distinguish morphological differences separating major groups of helminth parasites across multiple life stages, and apply that knowledge to identify unknown specimens Pre-Lab Materials Review the course syllabus before coming to lab.

item.title: Lab 2: Parasite Life Histories
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Define common vocabulary used to describe parasite life cycles (Simple complex, tropic transmission, parasitic castrator, vector-borne). Describe the life histories of a few major parasites of importance to human or wildlife health (malaria, Schistosoma spp, Ascaris lumbricoides, Guinea Worm, etc.) Apply their knowledge of parasite life cycles to develop targeted intervention strategies, and develop methods to evaluate their performance

item.title: Lab 3: Host Range and Parasite Specificity
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Perform the necessary steps to begin analyzing data in the R language (open a development environment, Create a new analysis file, load in analysis packages, load data into the environment). Create basic linear models in R and interpret their outputs. Understand potential drivers of parasite richness across species

item.title: Lab 4:Immune Responses
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Explain how the melanization response helps insects fight different types of parasites Perform dissections of Odontotaenius beetles and recognize common macroparasites of them Analyze empirical observations of parasite burden and immune response to make conclusions about which types of parasites illicit stronger host immune responses Pre-Lab Materials Before coming to lab this week, make sure to look over the learning objectives above, as well as the class presentation below.

item.title: Lab 5: Microparasites I
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Define a “model” and describe some of the ways disease models can help us gain insight Define and discriminate between state variables and parameters Explain how maximum likelihood approaches can be used to fit disease models Use functions from the bbmle package to fit epidemic models to real data, and then analyze resultant parameter estimates.

item.title: Lab 9: Tick Sampling
item.description: This week’s lab is a field trip! We’ll be sampling for ticks at Sesquicentennial state park. I’ve directly emailed you all with full information about times, where to meet, etc. Make sure to check it! Aside from participating in sampling, the worksheet also asks you to read Shapiro et al., 2017 to prepare for our class discussion of it next week! Presentation No presentation this week; we’re in the field!

item.title: Labs 6-7: Microparasites II
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Modify an epidemic model to include or remove compartments Draw a flow diagram to represent a compartmental model given a system of equations describing that model Given a flow diagram model, write a system of equations describing that system Explain the basic assumptions of the SIR model, and identify cases when violations of those assumptions may make it an inappropriate modeling choice.

item.title: Labs 6-7: Microparasites II
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Modify an epidemic model to include or remove compartments Draw a flow diagram to represent a compartmental model given a system of equations describing that model Given a flow diagram model, write a system of equations describing that system Explain the basic assumptions of the SIR model, and identify cases when violations of those assumptions may make it an inappropriate modeling choice.

item.title: Labs 8: Macroparasite Aggregation + Host Behavioral Effects
item.description: Student Learning Outcomes At the end of this lab, a successful learner should be able to… Presentation Lab 8 Presentation Worksheet Lab 8 Worksheet

Parasitology This document contains more information about the class and course policies. For more detailed information on course structure, click on syllabus tab above. For information on due dates, point breakdown, student resources, course expectations, etc., please see this pdf syllabus.

Syllabus Date Module Topics Read Code Lab Homework Week 1 home Course design, goals, introduction, and setup MODULE 1: Parasite diversity Week 2 Life history strategies and host-parasite coevolution Week 3 Parasite richness, specificity, and host range Week 4 Behavioral and immunological responses MODULE 2: Directly-transmitted parasites Week 5 Biology of microparasites Week 6 Epidemics and interventions Week 7 Parasite aggregation and burden MODULE 3: Non-direct transmission Week 9 Biology of macroparasites Spring break --- Week 10 Vector-borne disease Week 11 Environmentally-transmitted disease and sexually-transmitted diseases MODULE 4: Disease across scales Week 12 Infectious diseases in communities Week 13 Coinfection Week 14 Macroecology of infectious disease and networked populations Week 15 Zoonoses, spillover, emergence, and One Health MODULE 5: Closing thoughts Final exam week school Final exam (May 6; 9am)

item.title: Behavioral and immunological responses
item.description: Reading Ezenwa, V. O., Etienne, R. S., Luikart, G., Beja-Pereira, A., & Jolles, A. E. (2010). Hidden consequences of living in a wormy world: nematode-induced immune suppression facilitates tuberculosis invasion in African buffalo. The American Naturalist, 176(5), 613-624. de Roode, J. C., Lefèvre, T., & Hunter, M. D. (2013). Self-medication in animals. Science, 340(6129), 150-151.

item.title: Biology of macroparasites
item.description: Reading Viney M, Cable J. Macroparasite life histories. Curr Biol. 2011 Sep 27;21(18):R767-74. doi: 10.1016/j.cub.2011.07.023. PMID: 21959167.

item.title: Biology of microparasites
item.description: Reading Hopkins, S. R., Fleming-Davies, A. E., Belden, L. K., & Wojdak, J. M. (2020). Systematic review of modelling assumptions and empirical evidence: does parasite transmission increase nonlinearly with host density?. Methods in Ecology and Evolution, 11(4), 476-486.

item.title: Coinfection
item.description: Reading Viney, M. E., & Graham, A. L. (2013). Patterns and Processes in Parasite Co-Infection.

item.title: Disease
item.description: Reading Anderson, R. M. and May, R. M., Population biology of infectious diseases I Nature 280 (5721), 361 (1979). pdf available here Kilpatrick, A. M. & Altizer, S. (2010) Disease Ecology. Nature Education Knowledge 3(10):55 link to paper

item.title: Environmentally-transmitted disease and sexually-transmitted diseases
item.description: Reading Nordvik, M. K., & Liljeros, F. (2006). Number of sexual encounters involving intercourse and the transmission of sexually transmitted infections. Sexually transmitted diseases, 342-349. Lanzas C, Davies K, Erwin and Dawson D. 2020. On modelling environmentally transmitted pathogens. Interface Focus.1020190056 STD rates in Columbia, SC News article on Columbia as no. 3 rank

item.title: Epidemics and interventions
item.description: Reading McLean AR. Infectious Disease Modeling. Infectious Diseases. 2012 Dec 5:99–115. doi: 10.1007/978-1-4614-5719-0_5. PMCID: PMC7121366. Relevant video content Introduction to modeling infectious diseases

item.title: Exam review
item.description: Reading

item.title: Infectious diseases in communities
item.description: Reading Roche, B., Dobson, A. P., Guégan, J. F., & Rohani, P. (2012). Linking community and disease ecology: the impact of biodiversity on pathogen transmission. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 367(1604), 2807-2813.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Reading None for this week.

item.title: Life history strategies and host-parasite coevolution
item.description: Reading General background on parasite life history

item.title: Macroecology of infectious disease and networked populations
item.description: Reading Stephens, P. R., Altizer, S., Smith, K. F., Alonso Aguirre, A., Brown, J. H., Budischak, S. A., … & Poulin, R. (2016). The macroecology of infectious diseases: A new perspective on global-scale drivers of pathogen distributions and impacts. Ecology letters, 19(9), 1159-1171. Dallas, T. A., Aguirre, A. A., Budischak, S., Carlson, C., Ezenwa, V., Han, B., … & Stephens, P. R. (2018). Gauging support for macroecological patterns in helminth parasites.

item.title: Module 1 homework
item.description: Homework problems (feel free to copy and paste these over to another file and write your answers below each question) What are the different ways we can estimate parasite diversity? Clearly distinguish concepts of ‘diversity’ from ‘specificity’ What parasite group would likely have the lowest specificity, and why? In your answer, discuss parasite life history differences that are relevant to specificity. A botfly lays an egg inside the skin of it’s host.

item.title: Module 2 homework
item.description: Homework problems (feel free to copy and paste these over to another file and write your answers below each question) A new parasite is discovered infecting bess beetles in Mexico. Design an experiment to test whether the parasite exhibits frequency or density dependent transmission. This parasite is also found in Italy. How would you test for evidence of enemy release relative to other drivers of this parasite’s emergence in Mexico?

item.title: Module 3 homework
item.description: Homework problems How are the models of vector-borne parasites different from those of directly-transmitted parasites? When modeling sexually-transmitted disease, we observe a large variation in resulting infection time series (x-axis is time, y-axis is number of infected hosts). There were at least two reasons for this. What were they? How do we incorporate information about sexual transmission into our estimates of $R_0$? A waterborne pathogen has been affecting a local population.

item.title: Module 4 homework
item.description: Discuss the $c_{ij}$ parameter in Dobson 2004 American Naturalist paper (i.e., what is it? what do i and j stand for?). For a pathogen that can transmit across host species and within a host species effectively, what does $c_{ij}$ look like? Describe all the main proposed mechanisms underlying the dilution effect. Using literature we went over in class and from other sources (google scholar), write 4-5 sentences about the current state of diversity-disease relationships (in your reading, look for papers discussing ‘additive’ versus ‘substitutive’ experimental designs and discuss those)

item.title: No Lab this Week
item.description: No labs this week! Our first lab will be next week (01/17/2024) in Coker Life Sciences, room 201. Before coming to lab, make sure to review the syllabus and come excited to look at some parasites!

item.title: Parasite aggregation and burden
item.description: Reading Poulin, R. (2013). Explaining variability in parasite aggregation levels among host samples. Parasitology, 140(4), 541-546. Shaw, D. J., Grenfell, B. T., & Dobson, A. P. (1998). Patterns of macroparasite aggregation in wildlife host populations. Parasitology, 117(6), 597-610.

item.title: Parasite richness, specificity, and host range
item.description: Reading Poulin, R., Krasnov, B. R., & Mouillot, D. (2011). Host specificity in phylogenetic and geographic space. Trends in parasitology, 27(8), 355-361. Carlson CJ, Dallas TA, Alexander LW, Phelan AL, Phillips AJ. 2020. What would it take to describe the global diversity of parasites? Proc Biol Sci.

item.title: Vector-borne disease
item.description: Reading LaDeau, S. L., Allan, B. F., Leisnham, P. T., & Levy, M. Z. (2015). The ecological foundations of transmission potential and vector-borne disease in urban landscapes. Functional ecology, 29(7), 889-901.

item.title: Zoonoses, spillover, emergence, and One Health
item.description: Reading Plowright, R. K., Parrish, C. R., McCallum, H., Hudson, P. J., Ko, A. I., Graham, A. L., & Lloyd-Smith, J. O. (2017). Pathways to zoonotic spillover. Nature Reviews Microbiology, 15(8), 502-510. Cunningham, A. A., Daszak, P., & Wood, J. L. (2017). One Health, emerging infectious diseases and wildlife: two decades of progress?. Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 372(1725), 20160167.
